chapter.title: Mail Services (Overview)
chapter.para: Setting up and maintaining an electronic mail service involves complex tasks that are critical to the daily operation of your network. As a network administrator, you might need to expand an existing mail service. Alternately, you might need to set up a mail service on a new network or a subnet. The chapters on mail services can help you plan and set up a mail service for your network. This chapter provides links to descriptions of new features in sendmail, as well as a list of other sources of information. The chapter also provides overviews of the software and hardware components that are required to establish a mail service.
See for procedural information about how to set up and administer mail services. For details, refer to .

See for a more detailed description of the components of mail services. This chapter also describes the mail service programs and files, the mail routing process, the interactions of sendmail with name services, and the features in version 8.13 of sendmail. See .

sect2.title: Changes in the Solaris 10 Release

itemizedlist.para: Starting in the Solaris 10 release, sendmail version 8.13 is the default. For information about version 8.13 and other changes, see the following:

sect2.para: Additionally, the mail service is managed by the Service Management Facility. Administrative actions on this service, such as enabling, disabling, or restarting, can be performed by using the svcadm command. The service's status can be queried by using the svcs command. For more information about the Service Management Facility, see the smf5 manual page and Chapter 14, Managing Services (Overview), in System Administration Guide: Basic Administration.

sect1.title: Introduction to the Components of Mail Services
sect1.para: Many software and hardware components are required to establish a mail service. The following sections give a quick introduction to these components. These sections also provide some of the terms that are used to describe the components.

The first section, , defines the terms that are used when discussing the software parts of the mail delivery system. The next section, , focuses on the functions of the hardware systems in a mail configuration.

sect2.title: Overview of the Software Components
sect2.para: The following table introduces some of the software components of a mail system. Refer to for a complete description of all of the software components.

entry.para: Files that you can set up in a user's home directory to redirect mail or to send mail to a program automatically

An alternate name that is used in a mail address
A collection of mail messages that needs to be processed by the mail server
A special mail alias that is used to report problems and to ask questions about the mail service

sect2.title: Overview of the Hardware Components
sect2.para: A mail configuration requires three elements, which you can combine on the same system or provide in separate systems.

listitem.para: A mail host – A system that is configured to handle email addresses that are difficult to resolve
A minimum of one mail server – A system that is configured to hold one or more mailboxes
Mail clients – Systems that access mail from a mail server

sect2.para: If users are to communicate with networks outside your domain, you must also add a fourth element, a mail gateway.
